nodes.bodyText: isNull(numSplits)
For consistency I've kept the null checks as they were originally written prior to refactoring into this class.  Most of the code follows this pattern rather than using Objects.isNull.
Federation is different them ;)

Code Complet 17.1
Minimize the number of returns in each routine
Again this is existing code refactored into this new class, I'd probably stick with this return statement here as it provides a convenient short circuit to the meat of the processing.

I'm aware the code was pre-existing and not necessarily yours.
My comments where not change required.
one line? for (int nthCount = 0; nthCount < records.size(); nthCount++) {
isNull(operation.getInput())
Refactored existing code
How big is input expected to be, pulling the iterator into memory.

The code in AbstractSampleToSplitPointsHandler was refactored out of AbstractSampleElementsToSplitPointsHandler which already imposed a maximum sample limit before executing this code.
For the two new operations SplitStoreFromRDDOfElementsHandler and SplitStoreFromJavaRDDElementsHandler these also impose maximum sample limits before calling the operation.
It's possible a user might generate their own large sample, use this operation directly and blow the memory. Is that something we should guard against?
Not my call. My comment was more of a sense check and highlight for the reviewer.

@m29827 Yes if it's possible for a user to run this operation through the REST service, then it should be guarded against. However this can be disabled using a disableOperations.json file. There's one of these in the accumulo-rest, core-rest and hbase-rest modules (under rest-api). If you add the new operations to this list, then users will not be able to run them via the REST API.
@d47853 added the operation to the disabled operation lists as suggested

nodes.bodyText: Just a suggestion really but this operation should probably be called GenerateSplitPointsFromSample so that it's obvious what it does and follows the the verb-oriented standard of the other operations.

+ * The {@code SampleToSplitPoints} operation takes an {@link Iterable} sample + * and generates a {@link List} of split points from that. The sample and + * split points are normally UTF strings but this may differ for different + * Stores. + *

+ *

+ * You can manually set the number of splits using the numSplits field. If + * you don't set it then the Gaffer Store should calculate a number of splits + * for you. + *

+ * + * @param the type of splits + * @see SampleToSplitPoints.Builder + */ +@JsonPropertyOrder(value = {"class", "input"}, alphabetic = true) +@Since("1.12.0") +@Summary("Generates split points from the supplied Iterable") +public class SampleToSplitPoints implements

nodes.bodyText: Good point, I've renamed the classes as suggested
